definition_en: Used to refer to a specific or particular thing.
collocation: the book | the car | the end | the beginning | the best
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'the' correctly to refer to specific nouns.
prerequisite: Understanding of nouns and basic sentence structure.
error_pattern: Omission of 'the' when required | Incorrect use of 'a'/'an' instead of 'the'
teaching_method: Contextual examples | Gap-fill exercises | Error correction
sentence_1: This is the book I want.
sentence_2: The government is responsible for the welfare of its citizens.
sentence_3: The more you practice, the better you become.
status: 오류: API관리 시트에서 활성화된 API 키를 찾을 수 없습니다. API키를 입력하고 상태를 "활성화"로 설정해주세요.

definition_en: used to connect words of the same part of speech, clauses, or sentences, that are to be taken jointly.
etymology: From Old English 'and', related to Old High German 'anti' (at, to, against), from Proto-Germanic *andi ('over against')
collocation: and then | and so | and also | and yet | and therefore
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'and' to connect words, phrases, and simple sentences.
prerequisite: Basic vocabulary, understanding of nouns, verbs, and adjectives.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'end' in pronunciation | Incorrect placement in complex sentences
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate joining words and phrases | Practice sentence combining activities
sentence_2: She enjoys reading books and watching movies in her free time.
sentence_3: The research indicated a correlation between exercise and improved mental health, although further studies are needed to establish causality.

etymology: From Old English 'ic', from Proto-Germanic '*ek', from Proto-Indo-European '*eǵʰom' (I).
collocation: I think|I believe|I know|I feel|I mean|I guess|I hope|I understand|I remember|I imagine
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'I' correctly in simple sentences to refer to themselves.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns and verbs.
error_pattern: Confusing 'I' with 'me' in object positions; incorrect verb conjugation (e.g., 'I is' instead of 'I am').
teaching_method: Use picture prompts and role-playing to practice using 'I' in sentences.
sentence_2: I realized that I had made a mistake in my calculations.
sentence_3: I find myself increasingly drawn to the philosophical implications of quantum mechanics.

definition_en: Expressing direction or location; expressing purpose or intention.
etymology: From Old English 'tō', indicating direction or purpose.
collocation: go to | according to | close to | due to | in order to
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'to' correctly to indicate direction, purpose, and infinitive verbs.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns, verbs, and prepositions.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'too' and 'two'; incorrect preposition usage.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate direction; practice with fill-in-the-blank exercises; role-playing scenarios.
sentence_1: I am going to the store.
sentence_2: She went to the library to study for her exams.
sentence_3: The key to success is perseverance.

definition_en: Expressing the relationship between a part and a whole, belonging, origin, or connection.
etymology: From Old English 'of', meaning 'from, out of'. Ultimately from Proto-Germanic *af, *ab, meaning 'away, off'.
collocation: a lot of | kind of | type of | because of | made of | part of | instead of | out of | on behalf of | in front of
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'of' to show relationships between nouns, possession, and origin.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'have' in contractions (e.g., 'should've' instead of 'should of'). Incorrect omission or addition in complex sentences.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate relationships. Practice sentence completion exercises. Provide examples in context.
sentence_2: The quality of the music was surprisingly good, considering the venue.
sentence_3: The nuances of the argument were lost on the casual observer.

definition_en: The first letter of the English alphabet.
etymology: From the Greek letter alpha, which was derived from the Phoenician letter aleph, meaning 'ox'.
collocation: letter A | grade A | vitamin A
learning_objective: Identify and pronounce the letter A; understand its place in the alphabet.
sentence_1: A is the first letter of the alphabet.
sentence_2: She received an A on her exam, indicating a strong understanding of the material.
sentence_3: The 'A' in her report card was a testament to her diligent study habits, a clear indication of her mastery of the subject matter.

definition_en: the person or people that I am speaking or writing to
etymology: From Old English 'ēow', dative/accusative plural of 'þū' (thou).
collocation: you know | you see | are you | do you | thank you
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'you' correctly in simple sentences.
prerequisite: Basic subject pronouns (I, he, she, it, we, they).
teaching_method: Use role-playing and simple sentence construction exercises.
sentence_2: If you want to succeed, you need to work hard.
sentence_3: It is incumbent upon you to make the right decision.

definition_en: used to refer to a thing previously mentioned or easily identified.
etymology: From Old English 'hit', neuter pronoun, from Proto-Germanic '*hit', from PIE '*ḱe-', demonstrative pronoun.
collocation: it is|it was|it seems|it appears|it depends
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'it' correctly as a pronoun to refer to objects, animals, or situations.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns and pronouns.
teaching_method: Use real objects and pictures to demonstrate the use of 'it'. Practice substitution exercises.
sentence_2: It is important to consider all factors before making a decision.
sentence_3: The company's IT infrastructure is crucial for its daily operations, ensuring seamless communication and data management across all departments.

definition_en: used to identify a specific thing observed or heard by the speaker; used to introduce a subordinate clause.
collocation: that said | that is | that way | that time | that day
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'that' as a demonstrative, pronoun, and conjunction.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'this' and 'it'. Incorrect use in relative clauses.
sentence_2: I didn't know that you were coming to the party.
sentence_3: That he would betray their trust was beyond comprehension.

definition_en: Expressing the situation of something that is or appears to be enclosed or surrounded by something else.
etymology: From Old English 'in', of Germanic origin; related to Dutch 'in' and German 'in', from an Indo-European root meaning 'in'.
collocation: in the morning|in the evening|in a hurry|in love|in charge
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'in' correctly to describe location, time, and other relationships.
prerequisite: Basic vocabulary related to places and objects.
error_pattern: Confusing 'in' with 'on' or 'at' when referring to location or time.
teaching_method: Use visual aids and real-life examples to demonstrate the meaning of 'in'. Practice with fill-in-the-blank exercises and sentence construction.
sentence_1: The cat is in the box.
sentence_2: She is currently working in the marketing department of a large corporation.
sentence_3: The nuances of the argument are deeply embedded in the historical context, requiring a thorough understanding of the period.

definition_en: The male person or animal previously mentioned or easily identified.
collocation: he said | he thought | he went | he saw | he knew
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'he' correctly to refer to a male person in a sentence.
prerequisite: Understanding of nouns and basic sentence structure.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'she' or 'him'. Incorrect case usage (e.g., 'Him is going').
teaching_method: Use visual aids with male characters. Practice sentence completion exercises. Role-playing scenarios.
sentence_2: He decided to pursue a career in medicine after volunteering at a local hospital.
sentence_3: He articulated his vision for the company with remarkable clarity and conviction.

definition_en: used to indicate the purpose, recipient, or duration of something
etymology: From Old English 'for', from Proto-Germanic '*fura', meaning 'before, in front of'.
hyponym: for the sake of | for the purpose of
synonym: because of | due to | in order to | on behalf of
collocation: for example | for instance | for a while | for good | for sale | for free | for now | for sure
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'for' correctly to express purpose, duration, and reason.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns, verbs, and prepositions.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'to' when indicating purpose; incorrect prepositional usage.
teaching_method: Use real-life examples, gap-fill exercises, and sentence construction activities.
sentence_2: She is studying hard for her upcoming exams.
sentence_3: For all his efforts, he failed to achieve his goal.

definition_en: used to refer to two or more people or things previously mentioned or easily identified.
etymology: From Old Norse 'þeir', the nominative plural of 'hann' (he).
collocation: they say|they think|they believe|they know|they are
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'they' correctly as a plural pronoun.
prerequisite: Understanding of singular pronouns (he, she, it).
error_pattern: Confusion with 'there', 'their', and 'they're'. Incorrect verb agreement.
teaching_method: Use visual aids showing groups of people. Practice sentence completion exercises.
sentence_2: They decided to go to the park despite the cloudy weather.
sentence_3: They who seek knowledge must be diligent in their studies.

definition_en: physically in contact with and supported by (a surface); used to indicate the day or date on which something happens; concerning a particular subject
etymology: From Old English 'on', related to Old High German 'ana' meaning 'on'.
collocation: on the table | on the phone | on time | on sale | on purpose
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'on' correctly to indicate location, time, and topic.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns and prepositions.
error_pattern: Confusing 'on' with 'in' or 'at' when referring to location or time.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate location; practice with fill-in-the-blank exercises.
sentence_1: The book is on the table.
sentence_2: She insisted on going to the party despite feeling unwell.
sentence_3: The success of the project hinges on the team's ability to collaborate effectively.

definition_en: used to introduce an added statement, usually something that is different from what you have said before
etymology: From Old English 'butan' meaning 'outside, without', a compound of 'be' (by) and 'utan' (out).
collocation: but also | but not | but rather | but only | but then
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'but' to connect contrasting ideas in simple sentences.
prerequisite: Basic sentence structure, understanding of nouns and verbs.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'however' in formal writing; overuse in simple sentences.
teaching_method: Use sentence combining activities; provide examples of contrasting ideas.
sentence_1: I like apples, but I don't like oranges.
sentence_2: She wanted to go to the party, but she had too much work to do.
sentence_3: The evidence was compelling, but the jury remained unconvinced.

definition_en: used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself and one or more other people considered together
collocation: we are|we can|we have|we need|we think
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'we' correctly to refer to themselves and others as a group.
prerequisite: Understanding of personal pronouns (I, you, he, she, it).
error_pattern: Confusion with 'us' as object pronoun; incorrect verb conjugation (e.g., 'We is' instead of 'We are').
teaching_method: Use real-life examples, role-playing, and group activities to practice using 'we'.
sentence_2: We should consider all the options before making a decision.
sentence_3: We are committed to fostering a more inclusive and equitable society for all.

definition_en: to possess, own, hold for use, or be provided with
etymology: From Old English 'habban', of Germanic origin; related to 'heave'.
collocation: have a meeting|have lunch|have fun|have difficulty
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'have' to express possession, obligation, and experiences.
error_pattern: Incorrect use of 'have got' in formal writing; confusion with 'of'.
teaching_method: Use realia to demonstrate possession; role-play different scenarios where 'have' is used.
sentence_2: We have to finish this project by Friday.
sentence_3: Having considered all the evidence, the jury reached a verdict.

definition_en: to have information in your mind
etymology: From Old English cnāwan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kennen and German kennen.
collocation: know something | know how | know about | know of
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'know' to express understanding and familiarity with facts, people, and places.
error_pattern: Confusing 'know' with 'no' or 'now'. Incorrect verb tense usage.
teaching_method: Use flashcards, role-playing, and sentence-building activities.
sentence_2: Do you know where the library is?
sentence_3: He knows better than to argue with his boss.

etymology: From Old English 'wiþ', meaning 'against, opposite, near'.
collocation: with pleasure | with ease | with caution | with respect | with regard to
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'with' correctly to indicate accompaniment and possession.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns and pronouns.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'without'; incorrect preposition usage in complex sentences.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate 'with' in different contexts; practice sentence completion exercises.
sentence_2: She went to the party with her sister.
sentence_3: With all due respect, I disagree with your assessment of the situation.

definition_en: to exist; to happen; used to indicate the identity of a person or thing
etymology: From Proto-Germanic *bēaną ('to be, become'), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰúH- ('to grow, become, come into being').
collocation: be happy | be careful | be ready | be able to | be interested
word_family: being | was | were | is | am | are | been
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'be' in simple present and past tense sentences.
prerequisite: Basic pronouns (I, you, he, she, it, we, they).
error_pattern: Confusing 'be' with other verbs; incorrect subject-verb agreement.
teaching_method: Use visual aids, repetition, and simple sentence structures.
sentence_1: I want to be a doctor.
sentence_2: It is important to be aware of the potential risks involved in this project.
sentence_3: The key to success is to be persistent and adaptable in the face of challenges.

definition_en: The female person or animal previously mentioned or easily identified.
etymology: From Old English 'sēo', related to 'se' (that, the one).
collocation: she said|she thought|she felt|she knew|she looked
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'she' correctly to refer to a female person.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'he' or 'it'; incorrect pronoun agreement.
teaching_method: Use pictures and real-life examples to illustrate the use of 'she'.
sentence_2: She decided to pursue a career in medicine after volunteering at a local hospital.
sentence_3: She navigated the complexities of international diplomacy with grace and unwavering resolve.

definition_en: used to ask for information about something
etymology: From Old English hwæt, from Proto-Germanic *hwat.
collocation: What time | What day | What kind | What about | What if
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'what' to ask basic questions.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'which' when a limited set of options is available.
sentence_2: What I need is a good night's sleep.
sentence_3: What with the rain and what with the traffic, we were late.

definition_en: used to refer to the function or character that someone or something has
etymology: From Old English 'eall swā', meaning 'all so' or 'entirely so'.
hyponym: as if|as long as|as soon as
collocation: as soon as | as well as | as if | as long as | as a result
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'as' to make comparisons, indicate roles, and connect clauses.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of sentence structure and parts of speech.
error_pattern: Confusing 'as' with 'like' in comparisons; incorrect use of 'as' in complex sentences.
teaching_method: Use examples and sentence completion exercises to illustrate different uses of 'as'.
sentence_2: As the rain started, we decided to go inside.
sentence_3: As a seasoned diplomat, she navigated the complex negotiations with remarkable skill.

definition_en: used to make a statement negative
etymology: From Old English 'nāht' meaning 'nothing', a compound of 'ne' (not) and 'āht' (aught, anything).
collocation: not at all|not really|not yet|not only|not even
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'not' correctly to form negative sentences.
prerequisite: Basic sentence structure; understanding of auxiliary verbs.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'no'; incorrect placement in sentences.
teaching_method: Use substitution drills; provide sentence completion exercises.
sentence_2: She decided not to go to the party because she was feeling unwell.
sentence_3: Notwithstanding the compelling evidence, the jury remained unconvinced, not because of a lack of proof, but due to the defendant's persuasive demeanor.

definition_en: In order that; with the purpose that.
etymology: Combination of 'so' (Old English 'swā', meaning 'in this way') and 'that' (Old English 'þæt', a demonstrative pronoun).
collocation: use so that|study so that|work so that|plan so that
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'so that' to express purpose in complex sentences.
prerequisite: Basic sentence structure, understanding of conjunctions.
error_pattern: Incorrect use of tense after 'so that'. Confusion with 'such that'.
teaching_method: Provide examples, gap-fill exercises, sentence combining activities.
sentence_1: I study hard so that I can pass the exam.
sentence_2: She saved money so that she could travel to Europe next year.
sentence_3: The government implemented new policies so that the economy could recover more quickly.

definition_en: used to identify a specific person or thing close at hand or being discussed or referred to.
etymology: From Old English 'þis', neuter form of 'þes' meaning 'this, these'. Proto-Germanic *þat, from PIE root *to- 'that'.
collocation: this morning | this afternoon | this evening | this week | this year | this way | like this | this kind of
learning_objective: Students will be able to correctly use 'this' to refer to singular nouns near them or being discussed.
prerequisite: Basic noun recognition, understanding of singular vs. plural.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'that' in distance (physical or conceptual). Incorrect pluralization (this vs. these).
teaching_method: Use real objects and point to them while saying 'this'. Use pictures and ask 'What is this?'
sentence_3: This approach, while innovative, presents several logistical challenges.

definition_en: in or at that place; used to indicate the existence or presence of something
etymology: From Old English þǣr, related to that.
collocation: there is | there are | over there | there you go
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'there' correctly to indicate location and existence.
prerequisite: Basic subject-verb agreement, understanding of prepositions of place.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'their' and 'they're'. Incorrect subject-verb agreement after 'there'.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate location. Practice sentence construction with 'there is/are'.
sentence_1: There is a book on the table.
sentence_2: I heard there's a new restaurant downtown that's supposed to be excellent.
sentence_3: There has been a significant increase in the number of students applying to universities this year.

definition_en: Expressing location or arrival in a particular place or position.
etymology: From Middle English at, æt, from Old English æt ("at, to, near, from, by, in, on, for, against"), from Proto-Germanic *at ("at, to, near"), from Proto-Indo-European *ad- ("to, near").
collocation: at home | at school | at work | at night | at the beginning | at the end | at least | at first
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'at' to indicate location and time.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of nouns and pronouns.
teaching_method: Use visual aids and real-life examples to demonstrate the usage of 'at'.
sentence_2: She excels at playing the piano.
sentence_3: The company is operating at a loss due to the recent economic downturn.

definition_en: to perform an action; to work on something
etymology: From Old English dōn, from Proto-Germanic *dōną, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- ('to put, place, do').
collocation: do homework | do business | do a favor | do well | do badly
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'do' in simple sentences to describe actions and activities.
error_pattern: Confusing 'do' with 'make' in certain contexts (e.g., 'do a mistake' instead of 'make a mistake').
teaching_method: Use action-based activities, role-playing, and sentence-building exercises.
sentence_1: I do my homework every day.
sentence_2: What are you going to do this weekend?
sentence_3: The company will do well if it continues to innovate.

etymology: From Middle English 'no', from Old English 'nā', from ne (not) + ā (ever).
collocation: say no | no problem | no way | no doubt | no thanks
learning_objective: Students will be able to understand and use 'no' to express negation or refusal.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of sentence structure and question formation.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'know' or using double negatives incorrectly.
teaching_method: Role-playing scenarios where students practice saying 'no' in different situations.
sentence_2: Despite the pressure, she remained firm and said no to the unethical request.
sentence_3: The committee voted no on the proposal, effectively halting the project's progress.

definition_en: in a good or satisfactory way; in good health; a deep hole in the ground from which water, oil, or gas can be obtained; used to express surprise, agreement, or resignation.
etymology: From Old English 'wella' (spring of water, well) and 'wel' (fully, very, much), from Proto-Germanic *wallan (to boil, bubble forth) and *wela (well, good).
hyponym: artesian well | wishing well | oil well
collocation: very well | quite well | do well | well water | oil well | wish someone well
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'well' correctly as an adverb, noun, adjective, and interjection in various contexts.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of parts of speech (adverbs, nouns, adjectives). Familiarity with simple sentence structures.
error_pattern: Confusing 'well' (adverb/noun/adjective) with 'good' (adjective). Using 'well' as an adjective to describe nouns directly (instead of using 'healthy' or 'in good health').
teaching_method: Use real-life examples, role-playing, and sentence completion exercises to illustrate the different uses of 'well'.
sentence_1: I am well, thank you. | The water in the well is clean.
sentence_2: She speaks English very well. | The company is doing well financially.
sentence_3: The project was well underway by the time I joined the team. | Well, I never!

definition_en: every one or the whole number or amount of
etymology: From Old English 'eall', of Germanic origin; related to Dutch 'al' and German 'all'.
collocation: all day|all night|all the time|all over|all of
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'all' to express the totality of a group or amount.
prerequisite: Basic counting, understanding of nouns and pronouns.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'every' and 'whole'. Incorrect use with singular nouns.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to represent 'all'. Practice with simple sentences and fill-in-the-blanks.
sentence_1: All students must attend the meeting.
sentence_2: Despite all our efforts, the experiment failed.
sentence_3: For all intents and purposes, the project is complete.

definition_en: the lowest whole number; the first in a series; a single thing or unit.
etymology: From Old English ān, from Proto-Germanic *ainaz, from Proto-Indo-European *óynos (one, single).
collocation: one day | one time | one way | one person | one thing
learning_objective: Students will be able to recognize and use 'one' to express quantity and identify a single item.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'won' (Korean currency) or 'on'. Incorrect pluralization (ones is rare).
teaching_method: Use visual aids like counters or pictures. Practice counting and identifying single objects. Use simple sentences and repetition.
sentence_2: She is the one person who always understands me.
sentence_3: One might argue that the benefits outweigh the risks, but a thorough analysis is required.

definition_en: to find someone or something pleasant or attractive; similar to
etymology: From Old English 'līc' meaning 'body, form, corpse'; also 'similar, like'.
collocation: like a, like to, would like, feel like, look like
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'like' to express preferences and make comparisons.
error_pattern: Confusing 'like' as a verb with 'like' as a preposition; incorrect use of 'as' or 'such as' instead of 'like'.
teaching_method: Role-playing, picture prompts, sentence completion exercises.
sentence_2: She likes to spend her weekends hiking in the mountains.
sentence_3: The algorithm attempts to predict what content a user is likely to like based on their past behavior.

definition_en: exactly; only; or fair and morally correct
etymology: From Old French 'juste' meaning 'upright, righteous,' from Latin 'iustus,' from 'ius' meaning 'law.'
collocation: just a moment|just in case|just now|just about|just right
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'just' correctly as an adverb and adjective in various contexts.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of adverbs and adjectives.
error_pattern: Confusing 'just' with 'justice' or misusing its adverbial and adjectival forms.
teaching_method: Contextual examples, gap-fill exercises, and sentence construction activities.
sentence_1: I just want to go home.
sentence_2: He arrived just as the meeting was about to start.
sentence_3: The judge's decision was just, reflecting a commitment to fairness and impartiality.

definition_en: to be able to; a cylindrical metal container
etymology: Old English 'cann' (to know, be able), from Proto-Germanic *kunnaz (able, skilled).
collocation: can do|can see|can help|can you|can I
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'can' to express ability and possibility.
error_pattern: Confusing 'can' with 'may' or 'could'. Incorrect use of 'can' in past tense.
sentence_2: You can achieve anything if you put your mind to it.
sentence_3: The company can ill afford to ignore the changing market trends.

etymology: From Middle English 'or', from Old Norse 'eða' (either, or).
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'or' to present choices and alternatives.
prerequisite: Basic sentence structure, understanding of conjunctions.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'are' or 'our'. Incorrect placement in complex sentences.
teaching_method: Use real-life examples, games with choices, and sentence completion exercises.
sentence_1: Do you want tea or coffee?
sentence_2: You can either study hard, or you can fail the exam.
sentence_3: The efficacy of the treatment, or lack thereof, will be determined by the clinical trials.

hyponym: only if | even if | if and only if
synonym: provided that | assuming that | in the event that
collocation: if necessary | if possible | if so | if not | if only
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'if' to form conditional sentences.
prerequisite: Basic sentence structure, present and future tenses.
error_pattern: Confusion with 'whether'; incorrect tense usage in conditional clauses.
teaching_method: Use real-life scenarios to illustrate conditional sentences; practice gap-fill exercises.
sentence_1: If it rains, we will stay home.
sentence_2: I would appreciate it if you could send me the report by Friday.
sentence_3: If I were to speculate, I'd say the market will correct itself soon.

definition_en: to, in, or at a higher place or position
etymology: From Old English 'upp', related to Proto-Germanic '*upp-', meaning 'up, upward'.
collocation: up the stairs | up to date | up and down | look up | wake up
learning_objective: Students will be able to understand and use 'up' as an adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, and verb in simple sentences.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of spatial relationships and simple verbs.
error_pattern: Confusing 'up' with 'on' or 'over' when describing location; incorrect use in phrasal verbs.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate 'up' in different contexts; practice with simple commands and games.
sentence_2: She climbed up the ladder to reach the roof.
sentence_3: The company's profits were up significantly this quarter, reflecting a successful marketing campaign and increased consumer demand.

definition_en: on the subject of; concerning | used to indicate movement within a particular place or area | approximately
etymology: From Old English 'onbutan' meaning 'on the outside of, round about'.
collocation: talk about | worry about | know about | just about | about time
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'about' as a preposition and adverb in simple sentences.
prerequisite: Basic understanding of prepositions and adverbs.
error_pattern: Confusing 'about' with 'of' or omitting it entirely.
teaching_method: Use visual aids and real-life examples to demonstrate the different uses of 'about'.
sentence_2: She was about to leave when the phone rang.
sentence_3: The article is about the impact of climate change on coastal communities.

definition_en: indicating the person or thing that performs an action; near or next to
etymology: From Old English 'bī', meaning 'near, about, concerning'.
synonym: near | beside | next to | through | via
collocation: by the way | by far | by chance | by mistake | by now | by then | by oneself
learning_objective: Students will be able to use 'by' to indicate agency and proximity.
error_pattern: Confusing 'by' with 'with' when indicating the instrument used.
teaching_method: Use visual aids to demonstrate location; provide sentence completion exercises.
